column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0174] The PCR buffer also contains the deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (polynucleotide synthesis substrates) dATP, dCTP, dGTP, and dTTP and a polymerase, typically thermostable, all in adequate amounts for primer extension (polynucleotide synthesis) reaction.
#Text=The resulting solution (PCR admixture) is heated to about 90.degree.
#Text=C.-100.degree.
#Text=C. for about 1 to 10 minutes, preferably from 1 to 4 minutes.
#Text=After this heating period the solution is allowed to cool to 54.degree.
#Text=C., which is preferable for primer hybridization.
#Text=The synthesis reaction may occur at a temperature ranging from room temperature up to a temperature above which the polymerase (inducing agent) no longer functions efficiently.
#Text=Thus, for example, if DNA polymerase is used, the temperature is generally no greater than about 40.degree.
#Text=C.
#Text=The thermocycling is repeated until the desired amount of PCR product is produced.

#Text=An exemplary PCR buffer comprises the following reagents: 50 mM KCl; 10 mM Tris-HCl at pH 8.3; 1.5 mM MgCl.sub.2; 0.001% (wt/vol) gelatin, 200 .mu.M dATP; 200 .mu.M dTTP; 200 .mu.M dCTP; 200 .mu.M dGTP; and 2.5 units Thermus aquaticus (Taq) DNA polymerase 1 per 100 microliters of buffer.

#Text=[0175] Suitable enzymes for elongating the primer sequences include, for example, E. coli DNA polymerase I, Taq DNA polymerase, Klenow fragment of E. coli DNA polymerase I, T4 DNA polymerase, other available DNA polymerases, reverse transcriptase, and other enzymes, including heat-stable enzymes, which will facilitate combination of the nucleotides in the proper manner to form the primer extension products which are complementary to each nucleic acid strand.

#Text=Generally, the synthesis will be initiated at the 3' end of each primer and proceed in the 5' direction along the template strand, until synthesis terminates, producing molecules of different lengths.
#Text=The newly synthesized DNA strand and its complementary strand form a double-stranded molecule which can be used in the succeeding steps of the analysis process.

#Text=[0176] In one embodiment, the nucleotide sequence of the oligonucleotide tag is determined by measuring inorganic pyrophosphate (PPi) liberated from a nucleotide triphosphate (dNTP) as the dNMP is incorporated into an extended sequence primer.
#Text=This method of sequencing, termed Pyrosequencing.TM. technology (PyroSequencing AB, Stockholm, Sweden) can be performed in solution (liquid phase) or as a solid phase technique.
#Text=PPi-based sequencing methods are described in, e.g., U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=These disclosures of PPi sequencing are incorporated herein in their entirety, by reference.
#Text=See also, e.g., U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=Nos. 6,210,891 and 6,258,568, each of which are fully incorporated herein by this reference.

#Text=[0177] Pyrophosphate can be detected by a number of different methodologies, and various enzymatic methods have been previously described (see e.g., Reeves, et al. (1969) Anal Biochem. 28:282-287; Guillory, et al. (1971) Anal Biochem. 39:170-180; Johnson, et al. (1968) Anal Biochem. 15:273; Cook, et al. 1978.
#Text=Anal Biochem. 91:557-565; and Drake, et al. (1979) Anal Biochem. 94: 117-120).
#Text=[0178] In one embodiment, PPi is detected enzymatically (e.g., by the generation of light).

#Text=Such methods enable a nucleotide to be identified in a given target position, and the DNA to be sequenced simply and rapidly while avoiding the need for electrophoresis and the use of potentially dangerous radiolabels.
